awd_titl_txt: EAGER: MAKER: Enhanced learning through making by way of personalized content for animation and fabrication
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to impact the process of learning through Making by investigating an approach that allows future Makers aged 5 to 10 years old to provide input to educators who develop creative and unique physical or digital products that appeal to other K-8 student populations.  Through this research there is potential to provide better educational toys and artifacts that appeal to K through 8 students instead of the traditional educational products created through mass production. The idea that Making can support individualized educational products that are designed to the individual preferences of a child is exciting and novel.  This research investigates the impact of personalized content originating from children as a means to promote play as a form of learning. 
 
This research investigates innovative interactive design tools as a way of learning-through-making.  Also, this project assesses the efficacy of a museum Maker space and an afterschool program for working with educators and young learners. This project evaluates the impact of using hand drawings as a starting point to a complexly designed systems.  Qualitative analysis using inputs from play-testing sessions held at the Pittsburgh Children's Museum and afterschool programs will be used for comparison of the student populations. Designs and innovations using interactive software will enable novel Maker activities and empower broader audiences.  The additional experiences for young learners to become involved with mathematical models and computational software tools that automate tedious and challenging design tasks is exciting and novel.  The project expertly integrates Maker activities into an extensive engineering based learning environment in an informal way to expose and encourage the future STEM workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to test out an emerging platform, Simple VR, in an educational context. The platform allows users to upload 360-degree images, annotate them with words and recordings and view them in a VR headset. As a package of tools (the Simple VR platform and the 360-degree camera), we aimed to learn what supports were necessary for teachers to use these tools productively. Through this project, we partnered with a 6th grade, public school STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, Mathematics) teacher in the upper Midwest. Through this partnership, we built a relationship with the educator through observations, meetings and helping her in class. We co-designed a project for the students to redesign their school’s playground. By taking 360 photos in the playground, they were to annotate elements of the playground to imagine new ways of using the playground. This project also included non-tech elements, such as a planning and brainstorming phase and a public presentation as well. This project was implemented with multiple classes at the school.

            The pandemic presented challenges for the project implementing in subsequent years or in other settings. While the case of the implementation further contributes an example of project-based learning engaging students in content-related skills, such as engineering design and mathematics, the intellectual contribution of this work is to put forth a conceptualization of instructional coaching for technology-infused project-based instructional units. Rather than viewing the coach’s role as one that executes a gradual release of responsibility to the lead teacher, we saw the role of coach as increasing, decreasing and increasing again in its intensity as the project implementation unfolded. This could contribute to how the field thinks about building capacity for instructional coaches in project-based environments as well as how school leaders might think about allocating the time of coaches when working with other educators.

            The broader impacts of this project might point toward how the field of education considers providing ambitious teaching and learning experiences for all teachers and all students, especially project-based learning experiences. This project provided support for the teacher from co-designing the project-based instructional unit through the implementation of the project in the classroom. This suggests that support for project-based learning from instructional coaches may need to include varying forms of intensity over the course of the project—not just in the planning or initial launch of the project.

            In addition, the pandemic has made visible the importance of partnerships between practitioners and researchers and how that relationship does not need to be transactional. The pandemic has been/is difficult for all of us, but certainly has created many difficulties for educators. While the literature on research practice partnerships have increased in the last ten years, this literature naturally has not approached partnerships during a crisis. Much like the research practice partnership literature; however, our experience suggests that maintaining a long-term relationship with practitioners, even when there is no desire (or hope) for research, may be fruitful in the long run to better understand the context of the work and maintain trust as a collaborator.
